Defect engineering on BiFeO3 through Na and V codoping for aqueous Na-ion capacitors Wenyun Wang Chao Yang ⁎ Shangjing Yu Daotong Han Wentao Qi Rui Ling Guangqiang Liu ⁎ School of Physics and Physical Engineering, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, Shandong, China School of Physics and Physical Engineering Qufu Normal University Qufu Shandong 273165 China School of Physics and Physical Engineering, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The space and electric field effects triggered by Na doping and V doping, are considered as the synergistic effects to improve the Na+ transport and boost the pseudocapacitance of BiFeO3 for Na-ion capacitors. Sodium with low cost and high abundance is considered as a substitute element of lithium for batteries and supercapacitors, which need the appropriate host materials to accommodate the relatively large Na+ ions. Compared to Li+ storage, Na+ storage makes higher demands on the structural optimization of perovskite bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3). We propose a novel strategy of defect engineering on BiFeO3 through Na and V codoping for high-efficiency Na+ storage, to reveal the roles of oxygen vacancies and V ions played in the enhanced electrochemical energy storage performances of Na-ion capacitors. The formation of the oxygen vacancies in the Na and V codoped BiFeO3 (denoted as NV-BFO), is promoted by Na doping and suppressed by V doping, which can be demonstrated by XPS and EPR spectra. By the first-principles calculations, the oxygen vacancies and V ions in NV-BFO are confirmed to substantially lower the Na+ migration energy barriers through the space and electric field effects, to effectively promote the Na+ transport in the crystals. Electrochemical kinetic analysis of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors indicates the dominant capacitive-controlled capacity, which depends on fast Na+ deintercalation-intercalation process in the NV-BFO electrode. The NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors open up a new avenue for developing high-performance Na-ion capacitors. Keywords BiFeO3 Na+ storage V doping Oxygen vacancy Capacitor 1 Introduction The rapid development of renewable energy is essential for the sustainable development of human society. The emerging batteries and supercapacitors as high-efficiency and environmentally-friendly electrochemical energy storage devices, have played a significant role in the utilization of renewable energy [1,2]. The Li-ion capacitors have been deeply researched and widely applied for commercial energy supply [3]. Owing to high cost of Li on the earth, Na with low cost and high abundance is considered as a substitute element of Li for batteries and supercapacitors, which need the appropriate host materials to accommodate Na+ ions instead of Li+ ions [4]. Compared to Li+ ions, Na+ ions possess a larger ion size (1.02 Å vs. 0.76 Å) and a higher standard electrode potential vs. SHE (–2.71 V vs. –3.02 V) [4]. For Na+ storage, the host materials should exhibit the large enough channels to accommodate Na+ ions for fast Na+ intercalation/deintercalation process, which reflects the ion diffusion kinetics of the electrode materials. Numerous insertion-type electrode materials such as hard carbon [5], λ-MnO2 [6], V2O5 [7], NaTi2(PO4)3 [8], TiO2−x /CNT [9], MXenes [10] and K1.04Mn8O16 [11], have been explored for Na-ion capacitors with outstanding energy storage performances. The perovskite oxides with unique physical and electrical properties, have attracted enormous attention and shown wide application, such as electronics [12], piezoelectrics [13], catalysis [14] and energy storage [15–17]. The crystal lattice of the perovskite oxides with unique structural stability, can accommodate the mobile cations or anions under electrical polarization, which can provide the possibility for ion intercalation pseudocapacitance. For instance, the rapid migration of O2− in the crystal lattice of LaMnO3, accounts for its oxygen-vacancy-mediated anion intercalation pseudocapacitance [17]. Bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) as a typical ABO3-type perovskite oxide, has been previously reported to provide the remarkable energy storage performances, including high specific capacitances and wide voltage windows [18–20]. The charge storage mechanism of BiFeO3 depends on the transport of OH− or Li+ to produce intercalation pseudocapacitance, which is inevitably connected with the oxygen vacancy defects. The rational regulation of the oxygen vacancy defects is crucial to improve the ion transport property of BiFeO3. Theoretically, oxygen vacancies can be introduced into the BiFeO3 crystal through aliovalent cation substitutions and ion non-stoichiometry [14]. According to the charge compensation mechanism, aliovalent cation substitutions can make BiFeO3 to maintain the charge neutrality [21]. As a rule, the aliovalent substitution of Bi3+ or Fe3+ by a low-valence ion, can lead to the loss of lattice oxygen, along with the formation of oxygen vacancies. On the contrast, the aliovalent substitution of Bi3+ or Fe3+ by a high-valence ion, can increase the lattice oxygen content or reduce the oxygen vacancy content to some extent [21–23]. Recently, the V5+ doping in BiFeO3 has been utilized for the improvement of the remnant magnetization and coercive field [23]. Additionally, the V-doped BiFeO3 nanoflake network anodes have been prepared through a electrochemical method for the flexible asymmetric micro-supercapacitors with a Li-ion gel electrolyte [20]. Compared to Li+ storage, Na+ storage makes higher demands on the structural optimization of BiFeO3. It is really a challenge to obtain high-purity Na-preembedded BiFeO3, and manifest the effect of V doping on the electrochemical energy storage performances of Na-ion capacitors. Herein, we propose a novel approach to defect engineering on BiFeO3 through Na and V codoping for high-efficiency Na+ storage. The space and electric field effects triggered by Na doping and V doping, can be considered as the synergistic effects to improve the Na+ transport in the BiFeO3 crystal. BiFeO3- δ , Na0.2Bi0.8FeO3- δ , BiFe0.99V0.01O3- δ , and Na0.2Bi0.8Fe0.99V0.01O3- δ are prepared and denoted as BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO respectively. The morphology and structure of these samples are characterized by many necessary measurements, to certify the existence of oxygen vacancies and V ions. The electrochemical performances of these samples are compared through three-electrode tests, in order to confirm the effect of Na and V codoping on energy storage performances. The first-principles calculations in the frame of density functional theory (DFT), are conducted to reveal the roles of oxygen vacancies and V ions played in the Na+ transport. Electrochemical kinetic analysis of the symmetric capacitors (NV-BFO//NV-BFO), is used for the calculations of the capacitive-controlled contribution and the diffusion-controlled contribution to reveal the charge storage dynamic characteristics. 2 Experimental 2.1 Fabrications of BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO The samples were fabricated through a simple solution method and the subsequent annealing treatment. For example, 6.98 g Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.6 M) and 5.82 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.6 M) were dissolved in 24 mL ethylene glycol. The clear solution were dried in oven at 80 °C for 6 h, and successively heated in a mufflefurnace at 600 °C with the heating rate of 5 °C min−1, to obtain the BFO sample. The doped BFO samples were prepared through the above-mentioned method. According to the predetermined stoichiometric ratios, 5.59 g Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.48 M), 5.82 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.6 M) and 0.24 g sodium acetate (0.12 M) were dissolved in the mixture of 6 mL ethylene glycol and 18 mL acetic acid for the preparation of N-BFO. Acetic acid was used to facilitate the dissolution of sodium acetate. 6.98 g Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.6 M), 5.76 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.594 M) and 0.023 g VCl3 (0.006 M) were dissolved in 24 mL ethylene glycol for the preparation of V-BFO. 5.59 g Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.48 M), 5.76 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.594 M), 0.24 g sodium acetate (0.12 M) and 0.023 g VCl3 (0.006 M) were dissolved in the mixture of 6 mL ethylene glycol and 18 mL acetic acid for the preparation of NV-BFO. 2.2 Characterizations The morphologies of BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Carl Zeiss Ultra 55) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Thermo Scientific Talos F200X). The element contents of these samples were confirmed by the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) technology, which was conducted on Agilent ICPMS 7700. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Rigaku D/Max-cA X-Ray diffractometer with a Ni filter and Cu-Ka radiation (30 kV, 30 mA). X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) was conducted on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD using monochromated Al Kα X-ray beams as the excitation source (1486.6 eV). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was conducted by a Bruker EMXPLUS spectrometer operating in the X-band (9.84 GHz) mode at room temperature. 2.3 Electrochemical tests The electrochemical performances of the BFO, N-BFO, NV-BFO electrodes and the NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors were measured on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E). For the fabrication of these electrodes, the active material, acetylene black and PTFE were mixed with a weight ratio of 7:2:1 in deionized water to form a slurry, which was subsequently coated on a graphite felt with a mass loading of about 2 mg cm−2. The gravimetric specific capacitance (C) can be calculated from the GCD discharge curve as follow. (1) C = I Δ t m Δ V where I is the discharge current, Δt is the discharge time, m is the mass of active material, and ΔV is the voltage window. The energy density (E d) and power density (P d) can be calculated by using the equations. (2) E d = 1 2 C Δ V 2 (3) P d = E d Δ t Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed at open-circuit voltage from 105 to 10−2 Hz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Theoretical analysis of doping structure Fig. 1 showed the crystal structures of BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO, which focused on the change of oxygen vacancies caused by Na doping and V doping. For high-efficiency Na+ storage, Na+ ions can be preembedded into the lattices of BiFeO3 crystals through the aliovalent ion doping. The Na+ ion with the ionic radius of 1.02 Å, can take place of the Bi3+ ion with the ionic radius of 1.08 Å. Furthermore, the low-valence substitution of the Bi3+ ion by the Na+ ion, can reduce the content of lattice oxygen (OL) and induce the formation of oxygen vacancies (OV), in order to maintain the charge neutrality of the BiFeO3 crystal. These oxygen vacancies as the positive charge centers, can prevent the Na+ electromigration through charge-charge repulsion. However, these oxygen vacancies can accommodate more Na+ ions through the space effect, to the benefit of the Na+ transport. On the contrast, the V ions (V3+, V4+, V5+) with the comparative ionic radiuses to that of the Fe3+ ion (0.64 Å), can be employed for the high-valence substitution of the Fe3+ ion, which can inevitably suppress the formation of oxygen vacancies. Nonetheless, the V ions as the positive charge centers, are more positive than the Bi3+ and Fe3+ ions. The formation of the built-in electric field induced by V doping, can promote the Na+ transport in the BiFeO3 crystal. The space and electric field effects triggered by Na doping and V doping, can be considered as the synergistic effects to improve the Na+ transport in the BiFeO3 crystal. 3.2 Morphology and structure SEM, TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were obtained for the morphology characterizations of BFO (Fig. 2 a–d), N-BFO (Fig. 2e–h), V-BFO (Fig. 2i–l) and NV-BFO (Fig. 2m–p). Fig. 2(a and b) showed the morphology of irregular BFO nanoparticles. When BFO was doped by Na and V respectively, N-BFO exhibited the block shape with a larger size (Fig. 2e and f), but V-BFO showed the nanoparticle shape with a smaller size (Fig. 2i and g). These results indicated the regulating effects of Na doping and V doping on the micro morphology of BFO. Furthermore, the approximate square shape of NV-BFO reflected that the more dominant influence came from Na doping (Fig. 2m and n), mainly due to the higher doping content of Na than that of V. For Na doping, the use of acetic acid could affect the morphologies of N-BFO and NV-BFO to some extent, probably due to the stronger coordination of carboxy group in acetic acid with Bi3+ and Fe3+ than that of hydroxy group in ethylene glycol. Additionally, HRTEM images were employed to reveal the evolution of the lattice fringe spacing from BFO to NV-BFO. As a consequence, N-BFO exhibited the smaller average lattice fringe spacings of 0.2671 nm for the lattice plane (110) and 0.2180 nm for the lattice plane (202) than BFO (0.2691 and 0.2193 nm) (Fig. 2c and g) respectively, probably attributed to the smaller ionic radius of Na+ (1.02 Å) than that of Bi3+ (1.08 Å). From V-BFO to NV-BFO, the lattice fringe spacing also exhibited a decreasing trend from 0.2734 to 0.2701 nm for the lattice plane (110), as shown in Fig. 2(k and o). In addition, V doping could induce the increase of the lattice fringe spacing for the lattice plane (110) from BFO (or N-BFO) to V-BFO (or NV-BFO), probably due to the slightly larger ionic radius of V3+ (0.74 Å) than that of Fe3+ (0.64 Å). Compared with the SAED patterns of the previously-reported BiFe1- x V x O3 samples fabricated by the electrochemical method [20], the SAED patterns of these samples showed the excellent crystal structures (Fig. 2d, h, l and p), which were confirmed as the rhombohedral BiFeO3 (JCPDS 86–1518) [18–20]. More importantly, high-angle annular dark-field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of NV-BFO clearly revealed the uniform distributions of Bi, Na, Fe, V and O (Fig. 2q), reflecting the superiority of the preparation method. Structural characterizations of BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO were conducted by ICP, XRD, XPS and EPR measurements. The ICP results demonstrated the similar element ratios of these samples as the predetermined stoichiometric ratios in the preparation process, such as Bi1.006Fe1.000O3- δ (for BiFeO3- δ ), Na0.160Bi0.840Fe1.000O3- δ (for Na0.2Bi0.8FeO3- δ ), Bi1.000Fe0.993V0.007O3- δ (for BiFe0.99V0.01O3- δ ) and Na0.166Bi0.834Fe0.997V0.003O3- δ (for Na0.2Bi0.8Fe0.99V0.01O3- δ ), as listed in Table S1. XRD spectra of BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO all showed the characteristic peaks of BiFeO3 without other impurity peaks (Fig. 3 a), which were well indexed to the rhombohedral BiFeO3 with R3c space group (JCPDS 86–1518) [18–20]. Actually, the doping contents of Na and V played a significant role in the crystal structure of BiFeO3. When the doping content of Na was set as 50% and 80%, the obtained Na0.5Bi0.5FeO3- δ and Na0.8Bi0.2FeO3- δ exhibited the same impurity, which was confirmed as NaFeO2 (JCPDS 74–1351) by XRD analysis (Fig. S1a). Homogeneously, the existence of many impurities was demonstrated by XRD analysis for BiFe0.95V0.05O3- δ and BiFe0.9V0.1O3- δ , when the doping content of V increased from 1% to 5% and 10% (Fig. S1b). Hence, the doping contents of Na and V were set as 20% and 1%, respectively, in order to obtain high-purity doped BFO samples. Fig. 3(b) shows the magnified region of XRD patterns from 21° to 24° for the lattice plane (012), reflecting the almost unchanged interplanar spacing after Na or V doping of BFO. However, there was a minor change in the magnified region of XRD patterns from 31° to 33° for the lattice plane (110), indicating the slightly decrease of the interplanar spacing along with the increase of 2theta angles from BFO (or V-BFO) to N-BFO (or NV-BFO) (Fig. 3c). With Na doping, the interplanar spacing evolution of the lattice plane (110), was well consistent with the previous HRTEM results. Additionally, the 2theta angles of the lattice plane (110) were unchanged from BFO (or N-BFO) to V-BFO (or NV-BFO), indicating the negligible influence of V doping on the interplanar spacing, probably due to the relative low doping content of V. XPS spectra were analyzed to confirm the relative amounts of metal ions with different valence states and oxygen vacancies in BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO. The corresponding curve fittings of Bi 4f, Fe 2p, Na 1s, V 2p and O 1s were shown in Fig. 3(d–i), Figs. S2, S3 and listed in Table S2. The Bi 4f peak of NV-BFO was composed of Bi 4f 7/2 including Bi2+, Bi3+ at 157.5, 158.8 eV, and Bi 4f 5/2 including Bi2+, Bi3+ at 162.8, 164.1 eV (Fig. 3d) [18]. Compared to BFO, NV-BFO exhibited much higher atomic content of Bi2+, attributed to the Na and V codoping. In the annealing process, the Na doping could induce the formation of excess oxygen vacancies, which could decrease the valence states of Bi ions. In addition, the V doping could introduce the high-valence V ions (V4+, V5+) into the BFO crystal for the substitution of Fe3+, which could reduce the valence states of Bi ions through the charge compensation mechanism. The Fe 2p peak of NV-BFO was composed of Fe 2p 3/2 including Fe2+, Fe3+, a satellite peak at 710.0, 712.7, 718.2 eV, and Fe 2p 1/2 including Fe2+, Fe3+, a satellite peak at 724.0, 729.1, 733.4 eV (Fig. 3e) [18,19]. The V 2p peak of NV-BFO was fitted to be V 2p 3/2 including V3+, V4+, V5+ at 515.7, 516.4, 517.0 eV, and V 2p 1/2 including V3+, V4+, V5+ at 521.8, 522.8, 523.9 eV (Fig. S3d) [24–26]. It was worthy of noting that the fitted Fe2+ and V4+ peaks were predominant in the Fe 2p and V 2p spectra for NV-BFO and other samples (BFO, N-BFO and V-BFO). For maintaining the charge neutrality, the charge compensation mechanism accounted for the formation of the dominant valence states. By XPS analysis, the oxygen vacancies of NV-BFO were compared with those of BFO, N-BFO and V-BFO (Fig. 3f–i). The O 1s peak of NV-BFO was assigned to OL at 529.6 eV, OV at 531.6 eV and OH at 533.1 eV [27,28]. When BFO was doped by Na, the OV content increased sharply from BFO (or V-BFO) to N-BFO (or NV-BFO), due to the low-valence substitution of Bi3+ by Na+. When BFO was doped by V, the formation of oxygen vacancies was suppressed to some extent, attributed to the high-valence substitution of Fe3+ by V ions. Compared to N-BFO, NV-BFO exhibited slightly less oxygen vacancies, attributed to the relatively low V doping content. Furthermore, EPR measurements were used to reveal the evolution of the OV content from BFO to NV-BFO (Fig. S4). The OV characteristic signal of NV-BFO was stronger than those of BFO and V-BFO, and weaker than that of N-BFO, further confirming that the OV content could be increased by Na doping and reduced by V doping [27,28]. 3.3 Electrochemical performance of a single electrode Electrochemical performances of the BFO, N-BFO and NV-BFO electrodes were evaluated through three-electrode tests in 1 M Na2SO4 from −1–1 V. In Fig. 4 (a), CV curves showed three pairs of obvious redox peaks, probably ascribed to the reversible electrochemical reactions of Bi3+ [29]. According to the Pourbaix diagram of water (Fig. S5), the electrode potentials below the a line induce the HER, while the electrode potentials above the b line cause the OER. These electrochemical reactions as the competitive responses, can suppress the HER or OER to some extent, resulting in the stable voltage windows of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors. For Na+ storage, these multi-electron redox reactions mainly relied on the Na+ diffusion kinetics. The apparent diffusion coefficient of Na+ (D A) was calculated by the Randles-Sevcik equation [30] with the simplified form as follows. (4) i p = 0.4463 n F A C D 1 / 2 ν 1 / 2 α n F RT 1 / 2 (5) i p = D A ν 1 / 2 where α is the transfer coefficient. Fig. 4(b) showed the evolution of the D A values along with the charging/discharging process from A3 to A6, which were calculated from CV curves of the electrodes (Fig. S6). According to the equation (5), the D A values were obtained as the slopes from the linear relationship between i p and ν 1/2 (Fig. S7). The D A values at A1 and A6 were much higher than those at A3, A2, A4 and A5, reflecting the kinetic characteristics of the Na+ diffusion in these electrodes. More importantly, the NV-BFO electrode showed the highest D A values in the charging/discharging process among these electrodes, probably attributed to the effects of the Na and V codoping on the crystal structure of BFO. The gravimetric specific capacitances were calculated from GCD curves at different current densities (Fig. S8). The NV-BFO electrode exhibited the higher specific capacitance of 295 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and the better rate capability of 55.9% from 1 to 5 A g− 1, than the BFO electrode (240 F g−1 and 54.2%) and the N-BFO electrode (175 F g−1 and 55.1%) as shown in Fig. 4(c). In addition, all the coulombic efficiencies (CEs) were maintained close to 100% (Fig. 4d), indicating the good reversibility of the charging/discharging process. The impedance characteristics were comprehensively assessed by EIS measurements (Fig. 4e). The Nyquist plots were well fitted and expressed as a Randles equivalent circuit (Fig. S9), including the internal resistance (R s), the charge transfer resistance (R ct), the double layer capacitance (C d) and the Warburg element (W o), as shown in Table S3. The NV-BFO electrode showed the smallest R s value (10.3 Ω) among these electrodes. Additionally, the low-frequency region of Nyquist plots reflected the ion diffusion kinetics of the electrodes. The Na+ diffusion coefficient (D) was calculated from the sloping line in the low-frequency region of Nyquist plots, according to the following equations [30,31]. (6) Z re = R s + R ct + σ ω ω - 1 / 2 (7) D = R 2 T 2 2 A 2 n 4 F 4 C 2 σ ω 2 where Z re is the real part of Z plots, ω is the angular frequency, σ ω is the Warburg factor, R is the gas constant, T is the absolute temperature, A is the surface area of the electrode, n is the number of transferred electrons for per molecule, F is the Faraday’s constant, and C is the Na+ concentration. In Fig. 4(f), the NV-BFO electrode showed a lower slop (10.71) of Z′ against ω −1/2 than the BFO electrode (24.65) and the N-BFO electrode (14.44), resulting in the higher Na+ diffusion coefficient (1.524 × 10−11 cm2 s−1) than the BFO electrode (2.877 × 10−12 cm2 s−1) and the N-BFO electrode (8.383 × 10−12 cm2 s−1). In brief summary, the NV-BFO electrode exhibited the highest specific capacitance, the best rate capability, the smallest R s value and the highest Na+ diffusion coefficient among these electrodes. 3.4 Charge storage mechanism of NV-BFO The structural evolution of NV-BFO in the charging/discharging process, was analyzed through necessary ex situ measurements to reveal the charge storage mechanism of the NV-BFO electrode. Fig. 5 (a) showed the CV curve of the NV-BFO electrode at 10 mV s−1, along with the charging/discharging voltages marked as A–I. SEM and TEM images of the NV-BFO electrode indicated that the approximate square shape could be well maintained in the charging/discharging process (Figs. S10, S11 and Fig. 5b). More importantly, the NV-BFO electrode at the charging/discharging voltage of E exhibited the smaller average lattice fringe spacing of 0.2688 nm for the lattice plane (110) (Fig. 5c), than that at the charging/discharging voltages of A, C, G and I (0.2692 nm) (Fig. S11), probably attributed to the Na+ deintercalation-intercalation mechanism. Ex situ XRD patterns at the marked charging/discharging voltages, showed almost unchanged characteristic peaks (Fig. 5d), which were ascribed to the rhombohedral BiFeO3. The peaks described to the lattice plane (012) and (110), were magnified for confirming the possible changes in the crystal structure of NV-BFO (Fig. 5e and f). There was no significant change in the peaks of the lattice plane (012). In the charging process, the 2theta degrees of the lattice plane (110) shifted from 32.14° at A to 32.16° at E, indicating the Na+ deintercalation mechanism for charge storage. In the discharging process, the changes in the 2theta degrees of the lattice plane (110) from 32.16° at E to 32.15° at I, reflected the Na+ intercalation mechanism for charge storage. Additionally, XPS Bi 4f, Na 1s and O 1s spectra of the NV-BFO electrode at the marked charging/discharging voltages (Fig. 5g, h and Fig. S12), were well fitted (Table S4) to demonstrate the variations of the Bi2+ atomic content (Fig. 5i), the Na+ binding energy (Fig. 5j) and the OV atomic content (Fig. S13) in the charging/discharging process. The atomic content of Bi2+ at the charging/discharging voltage of E was much lower than that at the charging/discharging voltages of A and I, mainly due to the valence states of Bi ions enhanced by the Na+ deintercalation process. Furthermore, the binding energy of Na+ exhibited an increasing trend from A to E and a decreasing trend from E to I, reflecting the Na+ deintercalation and intercalation processes respectively. The atomic content of OV was relatively stable in the charging/discharging process, indicating the almost unchanged valence states of Fe (or V) ions through the stable FeO6 octahedra. Hence, all these results revealed the Na+ deintercalation-intercalation mechanism for this Na-preembedded BFO, which was expressed as follows. (8) Na0.2Bi0.8Fe0.99V0.01O3- δ −xNa+−xe− → Na0.2- x Bi0.8Fe0.99V0.01O3 − δ (9) Na0.2 − x Bi0.8Fe0.99V0.01O3- δ + yNa+ + ye− → Na0.2 − x+y Bi0.8Fe0.99V0.01O3 − δ 3.5 Theoretical calculations Theoretical calculations were further conducted to confirm the effects of Na doping and V doping on the Na+ transport in the crystals. Spin-polarized first-principle calculation was performed in the framework of DFT as implemented in the Vienna abinitio simulation package (VASP) program [32]. The generalzied gradient approximation was selected for the exchange–correlation potential [33]. The cut-off energy for plane wave was set to 450 eV. The energy criterion was set to 10−4 eV in iterative solution of the Kohn-Sham equation. The Brillouin zone integration was performed using a 3 × 3 × 2k-mesh. All the structures were relaxed until the residual forces on the atoms had declined to less than 0.02 eV Å−1. The differential charge density (Δρ) was calculated according to the following equation. (10) Δ ρ = ρ AB - ρ A - ρ B where ρ AB represents the charge density of the bulk structure, ρ A represents the charge density of the dopants and oxygen vacancies, and ρ B represents the charge density of the bulk structure after removing the dopants and oxygen vacancies. Fig. 6 (a) shows the differential charge density distributions of BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO. The yellow and blue regions denoted charge accumulation and charge depletion respectively. Compared with BFO and V-BFO, N-BFO and NV-BFO exhibited less charge accumulation regions, mainly due to the loss of O2− and the increase of oxygen vacancies along with the substitution of Bi3+ by Na+. Furthermore, the V ions marked by red circles in V-BFO and NV-BFO, showed more significant charge exchanges than the Fe ions marked by red circles in BFO and N-BFO, revealing that the substitution of Fe3+ by V3+ could enhance the charge polarization. It was worthy of mentioning that the V ions in NV-BFO were more conducive to construct built-in electric fields than the Fe ions, confirming the remarkable superiority of V doping. The oxygen vacancies and the V3+, V4+, V5+ ions confirmed by XPS spectra, could act as the centers of positive charges to facilitate the anion transport through electrostatic attraction. Additionally, these positive charge centers could induce the formation of the negative charge centers to construct fast Na+ transport channels. Hence, the oxygen vacancies and the V doping could establish built-in electric fields, to the benefit of fast anion and cation transports. The Na+ migration energy barriers of the Na+ transport paths in NV-BFO, were calculated through the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [34]. The Brillouin zone integration was performed using a 2 × 2 × 1 k-mesh for the calculation of the Na+ migration energy barriers. The Na+ transport paths in NV-BFO were rationally chosen to confirm the effects of oxygen vacancies and V doping on Na+ transport, including the Na+ migration routes from A to B (the position without oxygen vacancies), from C to D (the position with oxygen vacancies), from E to F (the position with oxygen vacancies and V doping), as shown in Fig. 6(b) and Fig. S14. The corresponding Na+ migration energy barriers were calculated to be 2.03 eV for A → B, 1.58 eV for C → D, 1.23 eV for E → F (Fig. 6c). These results indicated that the oxygen vacancies and V ions in NV-BFO could substantially lower the Na+ migration energy barriers through the space and electric field effects, to effectively promote the Na+ transport in the crystals. Hence, the NV-BFO electrode exhibited the best rate capability and the highest Na+ diffusion coefficient among these electrodes, mainly attributed to the oxygen vacancies and V doping. 3.6 Electrochemical kinetic analysis Electrochemical kinetic analysis of the symmetric capacitors based on two NV-BFO electrodes (NV-BFO//NV-BFO), was conducted by CV tests in 2 M NaOH and 1 M Na2SO4 respectively. Due to the faradaic pseudocapacitance characteristics at the potential window of −1–1 V, the NV-BFO electrodes can be used as the anode and the cathode for symmetric supercapacitors. In nature, the symmetric supercapacitors with the same anode and cathode, possess the higher matching degree of anodes and cathodes on the electrochemical process than the asymmetric supercapacitors. Hence, the symmetric supercapacitors can maintain the reversible electrochemical charging/discharging process rather than the asymmetric supercapacitors, though the asymmetric supercapacitors can take full advantage of different electrodes as anodes and cathodes. For the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor, CV curves showed three pairs of weak redox peaks in the stable voltage range of 0–1.8 V, which were marked as A1–A6 (Fig. 7 a). CV curves of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor showed a pair of conspicuous redox peaks in the stable voltage range of 0–2 V, which were marked as B1 and B2 (Fig. 7b). In theory, the current response (i) is related to the scan rate (v) in CV tests, according to the following equation [35]. (11) i = a v b where a is a constant and b is the power-law exponent. The b value can be obtained from the linear relationship between log |i p| and log (ν) for the anodic and cathodic peaks. As a result, the b values of B1/B2 in the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor, were larger than those of A1/A4, A2/A5, A3/A6 in the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor (Fig. 7c, d and Fig. S15), indicating that the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor showed more significant capacitance characteristics than the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor. Furthermore, the charge storage process can be divided into the capacitive-controlled and diffusion-controlled responses. Specifically, i can be divided into the capacitive-controlled contribution (k 1 v) and the diffusion-controlled contribution (k 2 v 1/2) [36,37]. (12) i = k 1 v + k 2 v 1 / 2 The k 1 value is considered as the slope, which can be obtained by fitting the linear curve of i/v 1/2 versus v 1/2 from CV curves at a arbitrary potential. For CV curves at 100 mV s−1, the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) and NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitors exhibited the capacitive-controlled contributions (84.2% and 85.8% of the total charge storage respectively), much higher than the diffusion-controlled contributions (Fig. 7e and f). In addition, the capacitive- and diffusion-controlled contributions to the total charge storage at different scan rates, were detailedly shown in Fig. 7(g), Figs. S16 and S17. It was worthy of mentioning that the capacitive-controlled contributions of the two capacitors at 10 mV s−1, were much higher than 50%, reflecting that the capacitive-controlled capacity was predominant at the scan rates from 10 to 100 mV s−1. Moreover, the capacitive-controlled capacity mainly depended on the Na+ intercalation pseudocapacitance, attributed to fast Na+ deintercalation-intercalation process in the NV-BFO electrode. 3.7 Electrochemical performances of symmetric capacitors Compared with the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor, the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor showed the wider operating voltage window and more obvious plateau in the discharge curve of GCD tests at 1 A g−1 (Fig. 8 a). Based on the GCD curves at different current densities (Fig. S18), the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor provided a gravimetric specific capacitance of 49 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 (Fig. 8b) with the coulombic efficiency of 84% (Fig. 8c), much higher than the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor (14.3 F g−1 and 81%). The Nyquist plots (Fig. 8d) were well fitted through Zview software according to the Randles equivalent circuit (Fig. S19). Compared with the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor in the high-frequency region, the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor exhibited a larger R s, mainly due to the SO4 2− anion with the larger size and lower electromigration rate than the OH− anion. The NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor showed a larger R ct than the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor, probably attributed to its higher pseudocapacitance. In the low-frequency region, the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor displayed a more vertical curve than the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-NaOH (2 M) capacitor, indicating its faster Na+ diffusion. In Fig. 8(e), the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor provided a high energy density of 27.4 Wh kg−1 at the power density of 1 kW kg−1, higher than the previously-reported supercapacitors based on Bi-oxides/Fe-oxides or Na+/K+ storage, such as Bi2O3/CNF//MnO2/CNF (11.3 Wh kg−1) [38], NiO//Bi2O3@C (6.77 Wh kg−1) [39], Bi2MoO6/Polyaniline//AC (25.7 Wh kg−1) [40], NiCo2S4//Fe2O3-RGO (14.2 Wh kg−1) [41], NMP//AC (8.08 Wh kg−1) [42], NMC-0.5//NMC-0.5 (4.66 Wh kg−1) [43] and NaNi4(PO4)3/GF//AC (19.5 Wh kg−1) [44] (Table S5). In addition, it was important to evaluate the leakage current and the self-discharge characteristic of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor (Fig. S20). After charged at 1 A g−1 to 2 V and kept at 2 V for 2 h, this capacitor retained a leakage current of 16.4 μA. After charging at 1 A g−1 to 2 V and holding at 2 V for 10 min, the open-circuit voltage gradually dropped to 0.49 V after 24 h. All these results indicated that this capacitor possessed a low leakage current and a satisfactory self-discharge characteristic. Based on the high energy density and the low leakage current, the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor could power various LED lamps with different colors, such as red (Fig. 8f), yellow and green (Fig. S21). Cycling stability and coulombic efficiency of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor were evaluated by consecutive GCD tests at the current densities of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 A g−1 for 10,000 cycles in total (Fig. 8g). This capacitor could maintain the capacitance retention of 81.0% at the end of the cycling test, and the coulombic efficiency of about 100% during the cycling test. According to the energy storage mechanism of the NV-BFO electrode, the reversible Na+ deintercalation-intercalation process accounted for the good long-term cycling stability of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO-Na2SO4 (1 M) capacitor. 3.8 Discussion on pseudocapacitance The morphology and structure of the electrode materials play a great role in the electrochemical energy storage performances. For example, the particle size and the surface area of the electrode materials can greatly affect the capacitance of the electrodes, including EDLC and surface pseudocapacitance, but not intercalation pseudocapacitance. In this work, these BFO samples (BFO, N-BFO, V-BFO and NV-BFO) exhibit the surface pseudocapacitance and the intercalation pseudocapacitance. These BFO samples possess poor specific surface area, mainly due to the relatively large densities. The V-BFO electrode with the relatively small particle size, can not provide a relatively high specific capacitance, mainly due to the lack of oxygen vacancies. The V doping can suppress the formation of oxygen vacancies, which can promote the Na+ transport through the space effect. Hence, the V-BFO sample is not the optimum selection for Na-ion capacitors. The BFO, N-BFO and NV-BFO samples have the similar particle size and specific surface area, resulting in the equivalent surface pseudocapacitance. By the electrochemical tests, the NV-BFO electrode exhibited the higher specific capacitance and the better rate capability than the BFO and N-BFO electrodes. Additionally, the NV-BFO electrode exhibited the higher Na+ diffusion coefficient than the BFO and N-BFO electrodes. By the first-principles calculations, the oxygen vacancies and V ions in NV-BFO are confirmed to substantially lower the Na+ migration energy barrier through the space and electric field effects, to effectively promote the Na+ transport in the crystals. Hence, the high intercalation pseudocapacitance of the NV-BFO electrode depends on its large Na+ diffusion coefficient, which can be enhanced by the strategy of defect engineering on BiFeO3 through Na and V codoping. 4 Conclusions The doped BFO crystals were prepared as the electrode materials for high-efficiency Na+ storage, in order to study the effects of Na doping and V doping on the electrochemical energy storage performances of Na-ion capacitors. The Na and V doped BFO samples were prepared through a simple solution method and the subsequent annealing treatment. XRD patterns confirmed the excellent crystal structures of all the doped BFO samples without other impurities. XPS and EPR spectra demonstrated the formation of the oxygen vacancies promoted by Na doping and suppressed by V doping. Based on three-electrode tests, the NV-BFO electrode exhibited the highest specific capacitance, the best rate capability and the highest Na+ diffusion coefficient among these electrodes. The first-principles calculations based on DFT, revealed that the oxygen vacancies and V ions in NV-BFO could substantially lower the Na+ migration energy barriers through the space and electric field effects, to effectively promote the Na+ transport in the crystals. Electrochemical kinetic analysis of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors indicated the dominant capacitive-controlled capacity, which depended on fast Na+ deintercalation-intercalation process in the NV-BFO electrode. Based on the new idea of defect engineering on BiFeO3 through Na and V codoping, the NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors held great potential for high-efficiency Na+ storage. coredata.dc:description: Sodium with low cost and high abundance is considered as a substitute element of lithium for batteries and supercapacitors, which need the appropriate host materials to accommodate the relatively large Na+ ions. Compared to Li+ storage, Na+ storage makes higher demands on the structural optimization of perovskite bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3). We propose a novel strategy of defect engineering on BiFeO3 through Na and V codoping for high-efficiency Na+ storage, to reveal the roles of oxygen vacancies and V ions played in the enhanced electrochemical energy storage performances of Na-ion capacitors. The formation of the oxygen vacancies in the Na and V codoped BiFeO3 (denoted as NV-BFO), is promoted by Na doping and suppressed by V doping, which can be demonstrated by XPS and EPR spectra. By the first-principles calculations, the oxygen vacancies and V ions in NV-BFO are confirmed to substantially lower the Na+ migration energy barriers through the space and electric field effects, to effectively promote the Na+ transport in the crystals. Electrochemical kinetic analysis of the NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors indicates the dominant capacitive-controlled capacity, which depends on fast Na+ deintercalation-intercalation process in the NV-BFO electrode. The NV-BFO//NV-BFO capacitors open up a new avenue for developing high-performance Na-ion capacitors.
